title: How I Deal With Sickle Cell Disease and Triggers I Can’t Control

content: At this stage in life, I know my body well enough to avoid having as many sickle cell crises as I used to. I have achieved this by becoming better at avoiding my triggers for a crisis. For example, I try not to expose myself to cold weather, exhaustion, and stress. Avoiding such common aspects of modern Western life is a whole job! What has been vital for me is recognizing that I can't always avoid triggers; accepting this and focusing on my recovery has now been the focus.

Sadly, it is winter now, so I'm exposed to one of my primary triggers for a crisis: cold weather. When it's cold, your veins constrict, which makes it more difficult for blood cells to pass through and increases the likelihood of a crisis. Keeping warm and staying hydrated have been my main counters to cold weather. However, there aren't perfect weather conditions where a sickle cell crisis is impossible.

In the U.K., we sometimes have sudden weather changes, making avoiding a crisis difficult. For example, in August 2018 (U.K. summertime), I was hospitalized because I wasn't wearing appropriate clothing for the change in weather. It was hot that day, so I wore shorts and left my jacket at home. Then, the temperature dropped in the evening, and it started to rain. As I began to shiver, I suddenly felt a feeling I knew all too well: the exposure to the change in temperature was triggering a crisis. This could have been avoided if I had planned properly and looked out for the weather all day. On the other hand, it's not always possible to prepare for all of life's eventualities, and this is a truth I had to accept.

sections.heading: Exhaustion
content: Exhaustion feels easy to avoid; I should sleep more, right? However, some of the symptoms of sickle cell disease are fatigue and issues with sleeping. There are multiple days where I feel I must push through beyond the tiredness to function like everyone else. For example, when I have work deadlines or commitments to stick to, it's not easy to say no and give the excuse that you are tired. I have learned to analyze a vital commitment and what can be missed or explored at another time. My word is my bond, but not when my health is at stake. For example, I had tickets to see one of my favorite artists the day before a long-haul flight for a holiday.

content: I was exhausted from work, and the U.K. had freezing weather conditions then. I was caught in a dilemma: to risk exposing myself to my triggers by going to a concert and then flying out the next day or selling my tickets. I was worried that pushing through the fatigue would set off my potential triggers. In the end, I sold my concert tickets. Selling my tickets felt like a step away from my usual can-do, push-through-anything attitude. A less sickle cell war-hardened version of me would have done both. However, this version of me has missed a lot during crises. In this scenario, I had to rationalize and choose what I would enjoy more, as both experiences would be unique. Ultimately, the holiday was the obvious choice and the right decision for my body. Through pre-planning and rest, I could have a crisis-free trip; additionally, the concert was streamed online!

sections.heading: Stress
content: Stress, at first thought, is also something that feels avoidable; indeed, there are ways to live a stress-free life. I have not been stress-free, and the demands of school, university, and now work have always been a source of stress for me. What is interesting about stress is how you respond to it. In the past, coupled with my ‘say yes to everything and keep going attitude,’ I never gave myself the ability to cope. In the workplace, how could I say no to more work? I don't want to lose my job. At college, how could I ask for more time on my assignment? I had to do it within the deadline.

As I have grown older, I have realized that if you don't ask, you won't receive. In hindsight, many of the crises I had in college could have been avoided if I had asked for more time. It was only when I was forced to go into the hospital that I asked for more time, which, if I had done so before, then I may not have built up all the stress that had put me there. With work, I am grateful that I can speak up about my capacity. Letting go of things that can cause stress or doing the self-work to manage stress better have been positive methods of managing stress and my overall health.
